awd_titl_txt: A New Paradigm for Non-Geosynchronous Satellite Communications and Radio Astronomy Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Spectrum is a precious natural resource for various active (transmit and receive) and passive (receive only) wireless systems, both of which provide several benefits to the society. However, phenomenal growth of active wireless systems and related spectrum allocations have caused less spectrum observation opportunities and greater chances of radio frequency interference (RFI) for passive wireless systems. One of the expansions of active wireless systems that deserves a special attention is the emergence of large-scale non-geosynchronous orbit (NGSO) satellite communication systems (SCSs). The prospects of such large-scale SCSs impose a distressing RFI situation to passive wireless systems such as radio astronomy system (RAS). Radio astronomy enables study of the universe, astro-physics and astro-chemistry as well as testing of the laws of fundamental physics, thus its growth is crucial for advancing science and knowledge discovery. The existing spectrum allocation/access paradigm is difficult to accommodate mutual growths of RAS and NGSO SCS. The purpose of this project is to develop a new paradigm for RAS and NGSO SCS where both types of systems can coexist and expand beyond what is achievable in the existing paradigm. Instead of viewing large-scale NGSO SCSs as a threat of RFI, this project views them as an opportunity to develop an integrated large-scale NGSO-SCS and NGSO-RAS system that can provide space-based RAS observation services, in addition to their main communication services. By enabling a large-scale NGSO-RAS, the proposed paradigm will open a new era for RAS with numerous enhanced capabilities and observation opportunities. This can lead to new exciting science discoveries on a larger scale. On the other hand, some spectrum originally allocated to RAS can be re-purposed for active wireless systems, thus stimulating more wireless applications and business opportunities for active wireless systems. The overall spectrum utilization efficiency will also be substantially enhanced.

This project introduces a new paradigm of spectrum access for RAS and NGSO SCS by means of transforming a large-scale NGSO SCS into an integrated large-scale NGSO-SCS and NGSO-RAS. This is different from the current paradigm where RASs implemented on ground are prone to RFI caused by SCSs, and conflicting spectrum needs from both SCSs and RASs cannot be resolved. To have broader applicability, the project considers three types of integrated systems: i) a system with all dual-purpose satellites (each with SCS and RAS receivers), ii) a system with a mixture of dual-purpose satellites and single-purpose SCS-only satellites, iii) a system with a mixture of single-purpose SCS-only satellites and single-purpose RAS-only satellites. For each type of the integrated systems, further detailed technical developments are as follows: 1) The project will develop innovative approaches for spectrum access and resource allocation needed for the new paradigm. The project will also study new achievable performance in terms of RAS data rate, SCS data rate, and outage performance. Furthermore, promising deployment scenarios and recommended changes of frequency allocation rules will be investigated for the new paradigm. 2) The project will study new capabilities of the proposed large-scale NGSO-RAS under several deployment scenarios and practical constraints. In addition, novel solutions to enable RAS observations in the bands assigned to higher-orbit satellite systems will also be developed. 3) The project will develop efficient data transport strategies for both delay-sensitive SCS data and space-borne delay-insensitive RAS data under several deployment scenarios and optimization metrics. Joint design of resource allocation and data transport will also be developed for further performance improvement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Non-geosynchronous orbits (NGSO), which include low earth orbit (LEO) and medium earth orbit (MEO), satellite communication systems (SCSs) have recently been evolving into an unprecedented era marked by mega-constellations of thousands of satellites. They will be providing broadband wireless access with unparalleled global coverage, thus benefitting consumers of various communication and information services. However, they cause concerns of radio frequency interference (RFI) to a radio astronomy system (RAS) which studies phenomenological science about the universe.  RAS receivers on the ground detect extremely weak signals coming from outer space; hence, they are very vulnerable to RFI from the communication satellites. To overcome this RFI hindrance to the scientific advancement of RAS, this project proposed and investigated a new paradigm where the RFI-causing mega-constellation satellites are turned into an infrastructure providing both SCS and RAS services.

The project provided the following technical solutions and insights.

1)     The main proposed solution is changing emerging mega-constellation NGSO SCSs into systems that provide both communications and radio astronomy observation (RAO) services. The investigation results indicate that it can provide several advantages as follows: i) RAO capabilities that are not achievable by ground-based RAO and/or that can be combined with the ground-based RAO for enhanced performance, ii) better protection of RAO against RFI, and iii) more spectrum access opportunities for both SCS and RAO services.

2)     As a large number of satellites will be conducting RAO under the proposed paradigm, the corresponding RAO data needs to be transported to the ground. The project developed low-complexity RAO data transport algorithms, studied the impacts of satellite system dynamics on the RAO data transport issue, and fine-tuned the data transport algorithms to handle the satellite dynamics.

3)     For the cost-effectiveness of the proposed paradigm, the project investigated several configurations of dual-purpose satellites where half or a quarter of the total number of satellites offer both communication and RAO services while the rest provide communication service only. The sunshade capability of the dual-purpose satellites influences the feasible RAO region on the orbital surface, which in turn affects the RAO performance. This represents a cost and performance trade-off. The best configuration depends on the RAO type, source direction, and feasible RAO region on the orbital surface. RAS community can set their focused RAO goals according to each life cycle of dual-purpose satellites and change them from one life cycle to another to meet their RAO needs. The DMEO satellite configuration should be adjusted according to the RAO goals for the NGSO-based RAS.

4)     A new air-craft-based communication infrastructure is introduced and its ground-centric and air-craft-centric connection probability models are developed. It can be useful in relaying RAO data from space to ground, as well as for other 5G/6G wireless systems.

5)     The project also studied and developed strategies for mitigating RFI from satellites to the ground-based RAO.

The project has trained four Ph.D. students toward their graduation. The whole Ph.D. dissertations of three of them and part of the dissertation of the fourth one are based on the research conducted in this project. In addition, the project provided training opportunities for two current Ph.D. students and parts of their dissertations will reflect their research work done under this project. Furthermore, the project facilitated an industrial internship training for one of the PhD students. The project's technical scope covers satellite communication, constellation configuration, radio astronomy observation, spectrum access, and RFI. Thus, the project also contributed to the development of a much-needed spectrum workforce. The research results of this project were disseminated in 8 peer-reviewed IEEE journal papers. The project also increases public awareness of the coexistence issue between communication and radio astronomy services. Via the disseminated research outputs, the project could influence industry and policy-making entities in their future activities relating to the coexistence of wireless services and enhanced spectrum utilization.
